stem: The nurse is caring for a client admitted with heart failure exacerbation. Based on the provided assessment data, for each finding, indicate whether it is indicative of Fluid Volume Excess or Fluid Volume Deficit.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
0700 S: Ms. Eleanor Vance, 82 y.o. female, admitted with increased SOB and lower extremity edema. States, "I can't catch my breath, and my ankles are so swollen!" Weight increased by 5 lbs since last week per patient report.
0715 B: PMH: Heart failure (Stage III), hypertension, chronic kidney disease (Stage 2). Meds: Furosemide 40mg PO BID, Lisinopril 10mg PO daily, Metoprolol 25mg PO BID. Last dose of furosemide given at 20:00 yesterday. Alert and oriented x3. 
0730 A: Auscultation reveals bilateral crackles in lower lobes. 3+ pitting edema noted in bilateral lower extremities. Bounding pulses. JVD present. Urine output decreased since admission. Labs pending. Currently on 2L NC with SpO2 92%. 
0745 R: Anticipate orders for increased diuretic dose, fluid restriction, and possible sodium restriction. Monitor vital signs, oxygen saturation, and urine output closely. Will update provider with lab results as soon as available.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
General: Elderly female, appears uncomfortable, SOB.
Cardiovascular: Bounding pulses, JVD present.
Respiratory: Bilateral crackles in lower lobes.
Integumentary: 3+ pitting edema in bilateral lower extremities, skin is taut and shiny.
Neurological: Alert and oriented x3.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
OrderDetails
Oxygen2L NC, titrate to maintain SpO2 > 92%
Furosemide40mg IV STAT, then 40mg PO BID
Fluid Restriction1500 mL/day
Sodium Restriction2000 mg/day
MonitorDaily weights, I&O, vital signs, edema

rationale.correct: Fluid volume excess (hypervolemia) occurs when there is an increase in fluid retention, leading to increased blood volume and interstitial fluid. Clinical findings include bounding pulses, crackles in the lungs, elevated BUN and creatinine levels (due to dilutional effect or kidney compromise), and jugular vein distension (JVD). Fluid volume deficit (hypovolemia) occurs when there is a loss of fluid from the body, which may manifest as flat neck veins and skin tenting.
rationale.incorrect: Flat neck veins and skin tenting are associated with fluid volume deficit, not fluid volume excess. Bounding pulses, crackles, and elevated BUN/Creatinine are associated with fluid volume excess, not deficit. Elevated BUN and Creatinine can indicate either fluid volume excess OR fluid volume deficit depending on the kidney's underlying ability to compensate; in this scenario the BUN and Creatinine are elevated due to kidney compromise in the setting of fluid volume excess.

answerBreakdown.rationale: Bounding pulses indicate increased blood volume, characteristic of fluid volume excess. The vital signs do not indicate hypotension or tachycardia that would be associated with fluid volume deficit.
Flat neck veins suggest decreased fluid volume, which is indicative of fluid volume deficit. JVD is not present.
Crackles in the lungs indicate fluid accumulation in the alveoli, a sign of fluid volume excess. The physical exam notes 'Bilateral crackles in lower lobes.'
Skin tenting indicates decreased skin turgor due to dehydration, a characteristic of fluid volume deficit. The EHR does not indicate skin tenting is present.

Elevated BUN and creatinine can occur in both fluid volume excess and deficit. In this scenario, with underlying kidney disease and fluid volume excess, the elevated BUN and Creatinine indicate compromised kidney function due to the fluid overload.

clinicalPearls: Assess for trends in vital signs (BP, HR) and lab values (BUN, creatinine, hematocrit) to differentiate between fluid volume excess and deficit.
Consider the patient's underlying medical conditions (e.g., heart failure, kidney disease) when interpreting fluid volume status.
Monitor urine output closely as an indicator of fluid balance. Decreased urine output can signify fluid volume excess.

questionTrap.trap: Students often confuse the signs and symptoms of fluid volume excess and deficit, particularly when patients have comorbidities like heart failure or kidney disease.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on understanding the underlying pathophysiology of each imbalance and how it manifests in different clinical findings.

mnemonic.title: Fluid Imbalance Mnemonic
mnemonic.expansion: Excess: Edema, Crackles, Elevated BP, Bounding pulse. Deficit: Dry mucous membranes, Decreased skin turgor, Flat neck veins, Fatigue
